wikipedia_page.main: Frederick Henry Johnson  (15 August 1890 – 26 November 1917) was a British soldier and  recipient of the Victoria Cross, the highest and most prestigious award for gallantry in the face of the enemy that can be awarded to British and Commonwealth forces.

response: * Frederick Henry Johnson, 73rd Field Company, Corps of Royal Engineers, 15th Division.

response: |Frederick Henry Johnson || British Army || 1915 || First World War || Hill 70

The college's archives contain a rich collection of artefacts relating to the history of the school as well as of the local area. The college works closely with Lewisham Historical Society and in 2018 the college's timeline corridor was opened showcasing original items dating back to 1888. To name but a few rare items, the school has an original lacrosse stick which dates back to the 1930's (the school was the first in the country to promote the game to boys), and the Victoria Cross belonging to Frederick Henry Johnson. The college also operates a dedicated site with digitalised archives which have been of fascinating interest for pupils, alumni and members of the local community.
* Frederick Henry Johnson, VC, recipient of the Victoria Cross in the First World War.

The memorial stands on a square of grass surrounded by iron railings and a paved area.  Plaques set into the paving in front of the memorial commemorate the award of the Victoria Cross to three men from the district: Frederick Henry Johnson, Geoffrey Cather and Alfred Fleming-Sandes.
